review_blob: Grapefruit and spicy herb flavour, honey coloured with a fizzy head.  Odd bitterness for an IPA, aftertaste lingers a bit too long.

I agree that newer microbrew have improved on the dry stout, but Guinness is the standard by which others are measured.  The Extra Stout is less creamy and more bitter than the Draught version, but retains the classic Guinness flavourings.  One of my favourites.

Sometimes I order one just to sit and watch the head settle from the bottom up.  Then I give it to the guy sitting next to me, so he can share in the perfection that is Guinness.  True, I have found several beers since my introduction to Guinness that I  overall like even better, but few rival the appearance and palate of Irelands pride.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: Very very berry.  The aroma overwhelms your nose upon opening a bottle.  Too sweet to drink more than one or two at a time, but a decent summer beverage, though it could pass for a trendy berry ice rather than a beer.  The underlying honey wheat beer is as good as Leinenkugels other offerings -- with a bushel-basketfull of berries thrown in.

Not so good.  The red colouring is nice, but thats where anything acceptable ends.  Bitter, not in a "Mmm hops" way, but rather a "what died and fell into the vat while brewing?" aftertaste. I couldnt smell anything recognizable.  Not completely horrible, but not worth the price.

Pours golden brown with an initial good head that dissipates quickly.  Tart/sour flavour completely overrrides any underlying woody or coffee undertones.  Bitter like an IPA but leaves an undesirable aftertaste.  An interesting experiment for NHB, but not something I recommend they repeat in the future.

Great coffee flavour, a thin mouthfeel but a complex mix including chocolate and oatmeal.  Thick creamy head, medium dark colour, slightly bitter aftertaste.  Light for a stout, but a good brew overall.

A simple beer, especially for Sierra Nevada.  Slight head and light carbonation, mild citrus flavour with a touch of bitterness.  Lacks the lemony/spicy twinge in many summer brews.  Good for a quenching summer drink, but you wont remember it by the end of the night.
Practically opaque dark beer with a twinge of red, tiny carbonation bubbles but not "fizzy".  Strong coffee and chocolate flavour, subtle aftertaste of chocolate and caramel.  Nice porter.
beer_name: Anderson Valley Deep Enders Dark Porter

review_blob: A great summer beer.  Smells like the grass you just cut and the grapefruit in the salad you had for lunch.  Dry hops, just the right bitterness, and some great looking lacing and carbonation.  A most excellent pale ale.

Once you get over all the chunks suspended in the beer, its pretty good.  Strong yeasty aroma, both fruity and spicy.  Not sure why its available in June when it is supposed to be a Winter seasonal...

Smells better than it tastes.  Fruity and hoppy, but flat and rather weak for an English bitter.  Decent to drink while reciting lines from "Life of Brian" with your friends, but not for regular consumption.
beer_name: Black Sheep Monty Pythons Holy Grail (Bottle)

review_blob: Not sure what's "extra strong" about this one - a pretty tame English Ale with very little carbonation and no head.  Bitter, but not as much as most of its type.  Caramel and roast, a bit of fruity aftertaste.  Great label, not so great Ale.

The bitterness is more in the aftertaste than upfront, and there weren't any other strong flavours immediately noticeable.  Crisp carbonation, though not a strong head.  Rather light for a "bitter ale"
Liquid toast -- light in colour, sharply carbonated, no strong flavours in any direction.  Stout junior -- a good trial stout for otherwise lighter beer drinkers.

Ah yes... a most excellent Porter. Much more coffee than chocolate in this one -- very bitter, very 'dark', very good.  Not a heavy aftertaste other than the lingering bitter flavour on your tongue, but I can't manage to find the "light cream finish" advertised in the commercial deScription.  Great porter -- get some if you can.

Bitter, dry, and malty.  I doubt it matters much that this is in a clear bottle... it's not "off" or "skunky" as much as it is just basic -- not an overwhelming flavouring in any direction.  My wife described this as "strong Budweiser".  While I wouldn't insult it that bad, I would say that it isn't a terribly unique beer.
Carbonated liquid green apples.  Very... appley, moreso than other hard ciders.  Light and crisp, hardly any head that vanishes instantly.  Skip it if it's not ice cold.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Thick thick dark creamy malty.  A "big" beer with strong complex flavouring.  Great if you like chewing your drink (and I do).
Fine Out Stout - light head, roasted malt flavour.  Nothing fancy but a good strong drink.
Burnt chocolate, moderately bitter.  A straightforward porter, representative of its style.
beer_name: Great Divide St. Bridgets Porter (St. Brigids)

review_blob: Crisp and spicy, the rye is very strong.  Lingering aftertaste is tempered by it being a thin beer that doesn't coat your tongue like other stouts.  Great for a cold night in January (that's why the woman on the bottle is so sad... she knows she's waiting another six months for winter to end in Michigan...).
Nice brown ale, nutty and sweet.  Mine was a bit stale, but I'm letting that go assuming it was from the clear bottle.  Little hops, limited aftertaste.
Great colour, more coffee than chocolate.  Not as thick as other stouts, but very nice nonetheless.
I love oatmeal stouts, but this one isn't the best representative of the style.  Thin and watery, not much "oaty goodness".  I expect more out of my Oat Stouts.
I agree with the "root beer" flavour deScriptions.  The bottle says "originally brewed as liquid bread".  If they were thinking raisin bread, they've got it.
Complex fruits, strong alcohol taste (obviously, at 10%).  Good colour.  My first quadrupel, so I'll likely rerate this one later after more tries.

Strange brew.  Bananas and citrus, but weak.  Nothing offensive in flavour, but nothing jumps out at you either.  Not the best looking beer... light head and fuzzy colour (bottle conditioned).  But the owl on the bottle is cool, so I'll probably buy it again when I can find it.
Among stouts, I like others better.  More bitter/hoppy than some, nice look in colour and head.  Hops noticable in aroma.  Still a good stout, great compared to general beers.

I could just look at this beer all day and be happy.  The best thing... the head would probably still be there when I finally drank it.  Great porter taste, dry chocolate-coffee... did I mention it looks great?  Excellent beer.
Fruity, some chocolate.  Not flat, but close... low carbonation.  Better looking than its flavour, but a pretty good amber ale.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: On par with Killian's, but this Red reminds me of why I prefer Stouts and Porters.  More bite than most US domestics, but that's of course not the best plug...

Cola beer.  Must be the toffee.  Heavily carbonated, very acidic aftertaste.  Much lighter than I expected from a Porter.  All in all, though, I'd drink it again perhaps if it was on discount - $5.50 a pint was a bit much for a beer soda.
Great looking head -- first impression.  Hoppy, a sweet initial taste, then you get the chocolate, the coffee, and... is that burnt toast?  Light for a double bock, good overall brew.

beer_brewer_name: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C; Group)
review_blob: Asti Spumante Cider.  Dry taste, dont wait for a head (its cider...), bitter while maintaining good flavour.  Looks terrible, smells great.  They do need to make the bottles bigger...
Umm... no.  Just say no.  Pick a different Petes, because he makes some good brews.  This just isnt one of them.
UPDATED: AUG 22, 2003

Strange brew, indeed.  Great red colour, bitter upon first taste that subsides after a few swigs.  Might as well light up when you start drinking this one, as itll fit right in with the palate... smokin.  Downright loamy.  It hits quick, but it doesnt last -- aftertaste is minimal.  Definitely try it if you like true Reds, not the American brewerys poor excuses for red beer.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: Good dark for beginners.  Remember, its a lager, not a stout -- just because its dark, dont expect the heavy, thick taste that many assume all dark beers have.  Good colour, flavour strong but less than some darks, fine aftertaste.  I havent yet found Leinenkugels Doppelbock, but this will do from them until then.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: Ok for a light beer, which is like saying Not bad for a Dodge.  The colour is good, but the flavour is predictably weak.  If youve gotta have light beer, drink this, then pay your tab and head home, ya weakling!

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: For once, an accurate commercial deScription.  Its light alright... light in color, light on flavour, light on honey.  It is crisp, but the lack of much honey flavour renders it indistinguishable from any other wheat beer.  Better than many of its type, but still mediocre.
UPDATED: NOV 19, 2005

Takes a few swigs to get used to, but then the quality of this beer becomes very apparent.  Rich and smooth, noticable alcohol mixed with a multitude of flavors.  Not intended to drink solo, though -- best with food to take away some of the bitterness (though not nearly as bitter as other double bocks).  Worth a try, good introduction to double bocks.
Spicy, somewhat of a bitter aftertaste.  Strong, but not as full-bodied as other bocks.  Good for a winter brew, though not something for frequent drinking.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2005
